I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) aim to support the post-coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) recovery in Mongolia’s primary and secondary education subsectors. It will 
(i) improve teachers’ knowledge and skills to assess students’ learning, (ii) enhance teachers’ 
skills in blended learning methods, (iii) strengthen schools’ management for post-COVID-19 
recovery, and (iv) assess the factors affecting learning loss and quality of learning outcomes. 
 
2.  The TA1 is a response to a request from the Ministry of Education and Science (MES) for 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) support for the recovery phase under the Comprehensive Plan 
for  Learning  Loss  Recovery  in  Primary  and  Secondary  Education,  2021–2023,  which  was 
developed by the MES to provide quality and continued education for all groups in Mongolia, 
especially during the COVID-19 emergency.2 The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 
operational  priorities  for  (i)  addressing  remaining  poverty  and  reducing  inequalities,  
(ii) accelerating progress in gender equality, and (iii) strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity.3 The TA is also aligned with strategic priority 1 of the country partnership strategy for 
Mongolia (foster inclusive social development and economic opportunity).4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Background. Because of the rapid spread of COVID-19, the Mongolian Emergency 
Commission temporarily closed all educational institutions and training centers on 27 January 
2020. Classroom teaching at all levels of education institutions shifted to online teaching. The 
advanced technologies have been used to continue education in the form of distance learning. 
These measures followed the comprehensive high-level emergency preparedness and public 
preparedness plans implemented by the Government of Mongolia. 
 
4.  Impact  of  COVID-19  pandemic.  The  pandemic  and  prolonged  lockdowns  had 
devastating impacts on education in Mongolia, which worsened already poor learning outcomes. 
The MES implemented measures to sustain the quality and accessibility of education services 
during the lockdown. Online and distance learning were organized through information and 
communication technologies throughout the country.5 Overall, children in rural areas received 
distance education for 100 days, or 20 school weeks (62% of the total academic year coverage), 
and children in the capital city for 110 days, or 22 school weeks (68% of the total academic year 
coverage) during school closures. Given the exacerbation of the COVID-19 pandemic situation in 
Mongolia since May 2021, the minister of the MES and the minister of health issued a joint order 
mandating the use of a blended learning scheme by combining both face-to-face and distance 
learning approaches at schools. As of 15 September 2021, about 55% of all schools nationwide 
were using face-to-face learning, 15% were using online-only schemes, and 30% were using 
blended schemes, taking into account the local pandemic situation. The future trend does not

2 
seem to allow for universal face-to-face learning, thereby requiring teachers to master the blended 
learning approaches.6 
 
5.  Information and communication technology gaps and learning loss. Inadequate 
information and communication technology infrastructure, especially in remote areas with poor 
access to electricity and the internet, and lack of sustainable and efficient online and distance 
learning platforms and resources have adversely impacted the access to and quality of education, 
especially for the poor. According to the MES and Mongolia Institute of Education Research 
(MIER) survey conducted in March 2021, 92.5% of teachers indicated that students’ learning loss 
was 40%–50%.7 The disruption to education systems has had a particularly huge impact on the 
education of girls, with a large proportion of them having limited access to distance learning during 
school closures. Even before COVID-19, about 73% of those children of primary school age who 
were not in school in Mongolia were girls. This trend is expected to be exacerbated by COVID-
19.8 
 
6.  Teachers’  inadequate  capacity  for  blended  learning  and  students’  learning 
assessment. Based on the “All for Education!” National Civil Society Coalition’s survey, 77.3% 
of teachers  indicated  that  their  workload  was  higher  than  before  the COVID-19  pandemic. 
Teachers were unprepared for online and distance learning. About 73.3% of teachers had never 
taught distance learning and only 20.0% had electronic devices with knowledge on how to use 
software and applications.9 Improving teachers’ knowledge and skills to implement the curriculum 
has been a big challenge in the past because existing in-service professional development 
programs do not assist teachers in adopting a child-centered methodology and the formative and 
summative assessments and evaluation methods required by the new curriculum.10 Therefore, 
teachers are required to improve their teaching and assessment skills not only in the classroom 
but also in distance learning using active and blended learning methods. Strengthening teachers’ 
knowledge and skills through providing continuing professional development (CPD) training is a 
major strategy to reduce learning losses among students. Teachers need better methodological 
and technical support for online teaching and formative assessment to track student progress in 
learning and target lagging students. At the same time, school leaders also experienced difficulty 
in managing and administering schools during the COVID-19 pandemic. 
 
7.  Strategic alignment and value addition. Recognizing the importance of providing quality 
and continued education for all groups in the country, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, 
the  MES  developed  the  Comprehensive  Plan  for  Learning  Loss  Recovery  in  Primary  and 
Secondary Education, 2021–2023 (footnote 2). The plan has 10 strategies within three objectives 
based on a three-phase "3R" model (reconnection, recovery, and resilience). ADB’s ongoing 
Sustaining Access to and Quality of Education During Economic Difficulties Project provided 
extensive support during the development of the plan.11 The reconnection phase has been 
 
6  At the beginning of the academic year 2021–2022, the number of infected children accounted for 19.8% of the total 
number of confirmed cases. Since the reopening of schools, blended learning has been exercised. The current rate 
of COVID-19 cases among children is less than 20% of total cases, which confirms that the blended learning system 
is an effective way to continue the learning process without worsening the pandemic situation.  
7  MES and MIER. Mongolia: Survey on Student Learning Gap. Unpublished. 
8  United Nations Children’s Fund. 2019. Learning Against the Odds: Evidence and Policies to Support All Out-of-
School Children and Adolescents in East Asia and Pacific. Bangkok. 
9  “All for Education!” National Civil Society Coalition. 2020. Teaching and Learning During the Quarantine of COVID-
19. Ulaanbaatar (in Mongolian). 
10 Assessments carried out during a learning–teaching process, while still in progress, are usually referred to as 
formative assessments. Summative assessment refers to learner outcome. They are typically used to assign grades 
and evaluate students.  
11 ADB. Mongolia: Sustaining Access to and Quality of Education during Economic Difficulties Project.

3 
implemented by the MES with the support of ongoing projects of ADB12 and the World Bank. The 
MES is requesting ADB’s support for the recovery phase which aims to develop and deliver CPD 
programs for teachers and school leaders to eliminate learning loss. In the third phase, which is 
the resilience phase, the MES, with support of other donors, will continue implementing the 
activities started in the recovery phase.13 As the face-to-face conventional learning scheme is no 
longer feasible in all schools during the COVID-19 pandemic, there is a need to strengthen the 
capacity of school managers and teachers to (i) assess students’ learning achievements and their 
learning environment, (ii) detect those students who are at risk of dropping out and provide 
support to them, (iii) use blended learning schemes, and (iv) create a better learning environment. 
The TA responds to the expressed needs of the teachers and students in the education sector to 
be prepared for and benefit from new modes of instruction and learning premised on the use of 
improved teaching  and management  and  performance  measurement methods in  the  post-
COVID-19 environment. 
 
8.  The TA will build on the ongoing ADB Sustaining Access to and Quality of Education 
During the Economic Difficulties Project (para.7 and footnote 11) which aims to sustain the access 
to and quality of pre-primary, primary, and secondary education during the economic difficulties 
that Mongolia has been facing (footnote 11). In addition to increasing the number of seats in 
schools and kindergartens, the project has been supporting the MES to improve the student 
learning assessment criteria and methods for primary and secondary education; introduce school-
based management; and develop and deliver CPD programs for pre-primary, primary, and 
secondary teachers through online platforms and workshops. This TA project will continue the 
capacity building of teachers and school managers through the design of CPD programs on 
students’ learning assessment, blended learning methods, and school-based management using 
the Institute of Teachers’ Professional Development (ITPD) online training platform. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: access to and quality of education in Mongolia 
improved.14 The outcome will be management of post-COVID-19 recovery in the primary and 
secondary education subsectors improved.15 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Teachers’ knowledge and skills to assess students’ learning improved. 
The following activities will be implemented: (i) a methodological e-handbook will be prepared for 
teachers  to  provide  guidance  for  developing  tasks  and  tests  following  student  learning 
assessment criteria; (ii) a CPD program including online modules to improve teachers’ skills in 
using formative and summative assessments will be designed for education agency staff, school 
managers, and teachers by subject and grades; and (iii) 130 specialists from education agencies 
will be trained as national trainers and 21,000 primary and secondary school teachers (60% of 
total) will receive online CPD program modules through the ITPD’s online platform.16 
 
12 ADB. Mongolia: Skills for Employment Project. 
13 A donor coordination meeting organized by MES was held on 25 November 2021 to identify possible partners to 
cofinance the implementation of the plan’s third phase.  
14 State Great Khural. 2020. Vision 2050: Long-Term Development Policy of Mongolia. Ulaanbaatar.  
15 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
16 The national trainers will be selected from the ITPD, MIER, the Education and Evaluation Center, local education 
departments, schools, and universities.

4 
11.  Output 2: Teachers’ skills on blended learning methods improved. The following 
activities will be implemented: (i) an e-handbook and video materials for teachers on blended 
learning methods will be developed free of gender bias and gender role stereotypes; (ii) a CPD 
program, including online modules on blended learning methods for national trainers and teachers 
in Ulaanbaatar and aimags (provinces), will be designed; and (iii) a CPD program will be delivered 
to 250 national trainers through online modules, and to 21,000 primary and secondary school 
teachers (60% of total) through the ITPD’s online platform. 
 
12.  Output 3: Schools’ management capacity for post-COVID-19 recovery strengthened. 
The following activities will be implemented: (i) an e-handbook and video materials on school-
based management  and  education  evaluation  will  be  developed  and  produced;  (ii)  a  CPD 
program, including online modules, to improve management and evaluation skills of school 
managers and social workers to eliminate learning loss will be designed;17 and (iii) a CPD 
program for 50 national trainers and 3,300 school managers and social workers will be delivered 
through the ITPD’s online platform. 
 
13.  Output 4: Factors affecting learning loss and quality of learning outcome assessed. 
To support the MES and MIER in identifying the key factors affecting the learning loss and quality 
of learning outcomes, the following activities will be implemented: (i) a research framework that 
is gender, disability, ethnicity, poverty, and geographically inclusive will be designed; (ii) data will 
be collected, including sex-disaggregated and analysis; (iii) a report will be prepared identifying 
key  conclusions  and  recommendations;  and  (iv)  a  final  workshop  will  be  held  with  key 
stakeholders to  discuss the findings  and  recommendations.18 The  TA  consultants  will  also 
develop a case study report to present the TA achievements. 
 
14.  Innovation and value added. The TA will introduce the CPD program in the primary and 
secondary education subsectors on blended learning methods and school-based management 
using the ITPD online training platform. It will support the development of methodological e-
handbooks  and  instructional  video  materials  for  capacity  building  of  schoolteachers  and 
managerial staff. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. 
 
16.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation for consultants, venues for meetings, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The Urban and Social Sectors Division of the East Asia Department will select, supervise, 
and evaluate consultants and monitor the quality of their work, in consultation with the MES (the 
executing  agency)  and  its  Department  of  Pre-Primary  and  Secondary  Education  Policy 
Implementation and Coordination (the implementing agency). The MES will be responsible for 
providing guidance and support to the consultants engaged under the TA and coordinating with 
 
17 The online modules for social workers will also cover child protection and gender sensitivity issues.  
18 The TA project team will also consult with education sector civil society organizations during the TA implementation 
for output 4.

5 
all associated agencies and institutions involved in implementing the TA. A project steering 
committee, chaired by the state secretary of the MES and comprising the directors of the MES 
and representatives of institutions such as the ITPD, MIER, and Education and Evaluation Center, 
will be established to review implementation progress and provide guidance on a semiannual 
basis. A technical working group will be established in the MES, comprising MES specialists and 
representatives from the ITPD, MIER, and Education and Evaluation Center, to provide regular 
support and guidance to the TA consultants during TA implementation.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Supporting Post-COVID-19 Recovery in Education Sector, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
